awd_titl_txt: Continuum Dislocation Dynamics Modeling of Mesoscale Crystal Plasticity at Finite Deformation
awd_abstract_narration:
Mechanical deformation of crystalline metals is caused by motion and interactions of defects called dislocations under applied forces or stresses. As the individual crystals deform, dislocation interactions lead to the formation of self-organized dislocation microstructures or patterns. These patterns are believed to control the mechanical strength and failure of metals. They are also important in metal manufacturing as they provide the way to refine the material behavior through combined mechanical deformation and heating. Although dislocation patterns were observed long ago, there is currently no theoretical or computational framework for predicting their formation in metals under arbitrary deformation. This research aims to bridge this critical gap by implementing a computational modeling framework that explicitly represents dislocations and their interactions at the mesoscale based on the continuum dislocation dynamics method. Such a generalization will enable accurate prediction of material behavior in crystalline materials, and it will eventually lead to realistic models of the manufacturing processes of structural alloys. Scientific knowledge obtained in this research will be incorporated into graduate curriculum and the developed tools will be disseminated to the wider research community. A particular focus will be given to the training of female and underrepresented students through graduate research assistantships.

The collective dislocation mechanisms that induce various dislocation microstructures in metal single crystals under deformation will be investigated by computational modeling. A recently developed computational framework based on continuum dislocation dynamics will be used as the method of investigation after generalization to finite crystal deformation. This modeling framework is theoretically founded to capture the full mesoscale deformation response of single crystals from dislocation properties, which includes the dislocation patterns, plastic slip distribution and crystal distortion, internal elastic fields, as well as the overall stress-strain response and average dislocation density evolution. The investigation includes the following research tasks:  formulating the governing continuum dislocation dynamics equations at finite deformation and coupling these equations with the stress equilibrium and deformation kinematics of crystals, solving the coupled system of dislocation dynamics and crystal mechanics equations using the finite element approach, building a community available code for mesoscale deformation of crystals based on the above, and simulating the dislocation microstructures of interest and validating the predictions using open literature microstructure data obtained by Transmission Electron Microscopy and X-ray techniques.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Research Performed:

This research aimed to develop metal plasticity models that account for dislocations and their interactions. This task enables a first principles prediction of the deformation-induced microstructure and associated constitutive behavior in single crystal. A recently developed computational framework based on continuum dislocation dynamics (CDD) has been generalized to the case of finite crystal deformation. This involved the formulation of the governing equations of CDD in both the spatial and referential materials frames and defining the relevant dislocation density and transport velocity measures. In addition, a thermodynamic underpinning of the constitutive closure of the governing equations of CDD at finite strain was completed. A novel part of this effort has been the definition of the Peach-Koehler force in terms of Mandel stress and dislocation core energy. Furthermore, the dislocation kinematics due glide motion was augmented by rigorous modeling of cross slip and reactions derived using graph theory and de Rham currents. Such a comprehensive formulation of dislocation kinematics opens new avenues for the exact treatment of dislocation dynamics in terms of the evolution of both dislocation and junction point densities. In deriving the dislocation transport equations, we have also asserted the critical importance of two, two-point dislocation tensors that were previously thought of as unimportant. These are the tensors connecting the dislocation density vectors in the referential and spatial frames with Burgers vectors in the so-called microstructure configuration of the crystal. These two tensors enabled the formulation of the transport equations for the spatial and referential density measures, thus providing a frame-invariant description of dislocations transport during plastic deformation. A novel Lagrange scheme was used to discretize the referential governing equations of continuum dislocation dynamics, together with the finite-strain crystal mechanics equations and show that the overall theory is capable of predicting the self-organization of dislocations in 3D, along with the stress-strain response.

Additional research tasks included the development of novel plastic strain and stress update algorithms suitable for the implementation of continuum dislocation dynamics models, the development and implementation of a phase field approach for the recrystallization in deformed metals starting from realistic initial conditions derived from the dislocation cell structure in deformed metals, the development and implementation of a data-driven coarse-grained cross slip implementation in continuum dislocation dynamics, and the development of a scheme to inform crystal plasticity models based on continuum dislocation dynamics.

Intellectual Merit:

The present work led to a number of important scientific developments linking the theory of dislocations and continuum deformation models for metal s and alloys. The physics of glide has been modified in this work to include core energy as part of the configurational forces acting on dislocations in a continuum description. Also, the kinematics of dislocation networks, as opposed to just lines, is now forming the basis of continuum dislocation dynamics by incorporating junction point transport along with the dislocation line transport. The network nature of dislocation systems takes into consideration the full crystallographic nature of dislocation reactions and it is an essential part of formation of junctions and thus hardening in metals. This opens the doors for understanding the role of these reactions in dislocation patterning in deformed crystals based on fundamental dislocation properties. Furthermore, the ability to solve complex dislocation network evolution problem and capture the density evolution and self-organization provides the ultimate tool for informing crystal plasticity model with lower scale information thus improving metal deformation simulations at the engineering scale.

Broader Impacts:

The research performed under this project has broader impacts in the science and technology of metals and educational workforce development. Two doctoral students have been trained in this area, one of them is now a staff scientist at a major materials simulations and software development company. The other is still a Ph.D. candidate at Purdue. An undergraduate student from Rochester University has been trained as a summer research program prior to his senior year and he is now a doctoral student in physics at UT Austin. Another Ph.D. student and a postdoc were preferentially involved in this work as well. The most important scientific impacts will occur in the areas of metal forming and recrystallization and the design and development of additive manufacturing alloys. We have already demonstrated the importance of including dislocation microstructure in recrystallization and informing crystal plasticity models using continuum dislocation dynamics simulations. Engineering simulations with such models represent the technological basis for metal forming technologies and will therefore impact on the making of metal products for civil, energy, and aerospace applications. Through these venues the research that was performed has an economic value. We currently have a reliable continuum dislocation dynamics code that we started sharing with the research community. It is anticipated that this code will serve as a future research tool for many projects in mesoscale deformation.


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: Anter A El-Azab
